ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:
Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: differential equations, mainly first order and second order
Solving typical differential equations, some relationships to applications in physics, etc.
I gained an insight into the key methods in solving first, second, and higher order ordinary differential equations and systems of homogenous linear differential equations.

Different ways of solving homogeneous and inhomogeneous first- and second-order linear differential equations, as well as systems of first-order linear equations. Fourier series and Laplace transforms, as well as basic numerical methods, also briefly covered.
A great introduction to ODEs. You learn a lot of useful techniques - methods of finding exact solutions, series solutions, and approximations

I learned about ordinary differential equations, and also their applications, primarily in physics. I learned how to solve first-order/second-order and homogenous/non-homogenous differential equations.
broad overview of ODEs
I developed an understanding of ordinary differential equations and how to solve them. The material was thorough and well-paced.
How to solve ODE's lol.
I learned how to approach differential equations along with proofs for them

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: It was difficult over zoom, but overall a pretty straightforward class. We very much follow the textbook.

Fairly straightforward, low stress class, but was taught straight from reading off professor's notes - sometimes for later topics it was easier to comprehend by reading textbook that notes were based on directly

I believe that this course does a good job of covering a number of different topics, however one weakness is that there was not as much focus on numerical methods of approximating solutions to complex equations.

Professor Moncrief really knows the material, and its presented concisely. All the notes were put online ahead of time, which is great. The only small issue is it was just a lot of information rather than being interactive. That could just be because of COVID

Strengths: the course comprehensively covered ODE and the material we were tested on was very relevant to what we learned in class. I also liked it when we covered practically relevant applications of ODE.
Weaknesses: this might be a function of the virtual environment, but I would have preferred if there was blackboard work instead of just scrolling through notes.
Strengths -- thorough and well-paced (not too fast, not too slow).

Strengths: learn diff eq
Weakness: not as engaging I assume because of covid

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Though it would take much longer, I think using a virtual whiteboard as opposed to pre-written notes could be an improvement in the virtual teaching setting.
Instead of reading off notes, it would help with the pace of class and student understanding to rewrite them live and talk through ideas.

I belief that the course was well suited towards virtual learning. The lectures were very helpful and recorded to help students avoid conflicts and I liked the fact that the assignments could all be done in a take-home format.
The virtual lectures were great! Its nice that they were recorded

The lectures were always posted on time and were helpful. In addition, posting the lecture notes was very helpful. As mentioned previously, I wish there could have been some actual working out of the equations as opposed to simply reading notes.

This course isn't meant for zoom... The content is already quite dry so focusing through zoom is even more of a challenge. Also, Professor Moncrief's transition to prewritten notes lets him speed though the content (since he doesn't have to write on the chalkboard), and often he gives you example problems but since they're prewritten instead of going over what he did he just kinda gives you the option to look things over more thoroughly later (and since everything's online there was less incentive to ask him to slow down). I really wish we could've done hands on work in this class, the later p-sets get quite complex and with no in class practice it often felt like I was grasping at straws.

...also Moncrief's handwriting can be difficult to read

I think what succeeded were the live lectures and the fact that they were recorded. That allowed me to watch and re-watch lectures and I realized that I was not bad at the material, I just needed to review it a few more times than others to fully understand the material. Recorded lectures are a big plus!
It could have been more interactive with notes

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Yes, I liked Professor Moncrief and the material was interesting.
For a fairly easy upper level math credit, sure.

If you would like to learn about the theory behind differential equations, definitely take this class. However, if you are looking to only learn the applications, take the ENAS class on differential equations instead.
It's probably better in-person. Lectures added very little beyond what could be gathered from simply reading the text.
Definitely! The material is actually really cool if you give it a chance, and the Professor is very kind.

I guess. I'll be frank, its a dry/ pretty boring course. At the beginning its quite easy but it gets a lot more complex/ tedious later on in the course (especially if its you're first time dealing with matrices). This was definitely the course I needed the most outside material to understand, lectures are pretty dull (as will evident when class attendance starts to wane) and the text book is thorough, but seems unnecessarily confusing once you know what you're doing. There's also no peer tutors so you're on your own if you don't know others in the class. that being said Moncrief is (surprisingly?) chill, he's really good at responding to emails and always gives off the impression that he willing to help you with anything. But overall, the class is still pretty boring and I think a lot of differential calculus is too arbitrary to really have much intuition for (in the sense that there'll be no logic the way the formulas you get in class other were developed than some guy stared at the problem for a long time and took a hella good guess). As a result, it doesn't really feel like you learn much? You DO a lot, but I've no idea the actual applications or scenarios I'd actually want to use half the stuff we learned... I'd say only take it if you need to for some reason or if you have a kink for doing page long calculations...

Side-note: taking concurrently with linear algebra (MATH225) can be quite fruitful. By the time the stuff involving linear algebra comes, you'll have leaned enough from MATH225 to understand some of the basic theory. The more complex stuff will probably go over you're head but since this isn't a proof based class you only really need the calculations. However, the linear algebra related calculations done in this class are some of the more annoying calculations you'll encounter in MATH225 (which doesn't focus much on the computation). Encountering them in both classes gives you good practice and basically does the studying for you.
Yes, it's an easy math major course and the content is very applicable in a lot of settings.
Yes, I would recommend this course as it is thorough and challenging and taught me the ODE material really well.

I mean if you're looking at it, you probably have to take it. I think it's better than ENAS 194, which seems like more work. MATH 246 is "more theoretical," but that really just means that you have to write like 2 proofs on problem sets over the course of the semester.
yes! it was very fun and interesting to learn. it does take time to get a hang of the concepts, but overall it was a great course.

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: Recorded lectures also available afterwards.
Textbook, office hours, live virtual lectures
N/A
Also viewed recorded lectures when I could not attend synchronously.
Only live virtual lectures
none
